thread.title: Recovery effort ahead at collapsed ice cave
thread.title_full: Recovery effort ahead at collapsed ice cave | The Seattle Times

author: Lewis Kamb
title: Recovery effort ahead at collapsed ice cave
text:
The Snohomish County sheriff’s incident-command vehicle led a stream of search-and-rescue vehicles about 7:30 a.m. Tuesday to the Big Four Ice Caves trailhead, about 15 miles outside the Verlot Ranger Station east of Granite Falls.
One person was killed late Monday afternoon when ice and rock collapsed near the mouth of the popular caves, and five others were injured, two seriously, said sheriff’s spokeswoman Shari Ireton.
The body of the deceased hiker was not recovered Monday “because conditions of the ice are so dangerous at this point, teams from Everett Mountain Rescue and other search-and-rescue volunteers are looking at conditions of the ice to see how safe it is before they go in,” Ireton said.
The road has been closed to vehicle and foot traffic while recovery efforts continue.
 A 25-year-old man was upgraded Tuesday morning from critical to serious condition and is in intensive care, said Harborview Medical Center spokeswoman Susan Gregg.
Also at Harborview, a 35-year-old man was upgraded from serious to satisfactory condition and is no longer in intensive care. A 35-year-old woman was treated and released Monday night, Gregg said.
In addition, a girl and boy were taken to Providence Regional Medical Center in Everett with minor injuries and have been released, according to Colleen Wadden, a Providence spokeswoman.
Lewis Kamb: lkamb@seattletimes.com or (206) 464-2932. Twitter @lewiskamb
